summary: This is a letter motion from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, requesting that the birth certificates of the minor victims be deemed self-authenticating under Federal Rule of Evidence 902 to avoid calling records custodians from five state agencies to testify at trial. The government argues the certified, sealed copies meet legal standards for self-authentication.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this letter motion is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter motion.

connections.description: Prosecutor submitting a legal motion to the presiding judge in the case.
Defendant and presiding judge in the criminal case.

events.title: Government Motion on Birth Certificate Authentication
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files a motion requesting the court to rule that the birth certificates of minor victims are self-authenticating documents under Federal Rule of Evidence 902.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services
Town of North Hempstead, Nassau County, New York
Massachusetts Department of Public Health Registry of Vital Records and Statistics
keyFacts: The government has obtained certified birth certificates for multiple minor victims (referred to as Minor Victim-1 through Minor Victim-6) from various state agencies.
The defense has not agreed to stipulate to the authenticity of these birth certificates, prompting this motion to have them declared self-authenticating.
The motion seeks to avoid calling records custodians from five different state agencies to testify at trial.
The birth certificates are from Rhode Island, Missouri, New York (Nassau County), California (Sacramento County), and Massachusetts.
The government references that certain victims and witnesses are testifying under pseudonyms, per a prior court order.
